comments.raw_text: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:2.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/4.0 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:2.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/4.0 It is currently impossible to access the coordinates of the last point that was drawn in the context. For example, after invoking (where context = theCanvas.getContext('2d')) context.moveTo(10,100); the coordinates are 10 and 100, and after invoking context.lineTo(1,2); the last point is (1,2). Adding the CanvasRenderingContext2D.prototype such properties (say, context.mozLastX and context.mozLastY) will allow web developers to add new functions to the CanvasRenderingContext2D.prototype, such as arrowTo and waveTo. These functions cannot be written without calculating the drawn line's slope, a calculation that requires these coordinates. Reproducible: Always This should be pretty easy since you probably already have these coordinates for existing functions (such as lineTo), and now you just need to turn them public.

comments.raw_text: I don't have any strong objections.

To add another use case:

Many solutions to this problem involve keeping track of the end point in some wrapper. However, when using arcTo(), the endpoint is unknown as it draws the arc using tangents.

Starting a new path from the endpoint of arcTo() is currently impossible without having to calculate the endpoint yourself
